ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Gained further insight into: French grammar, speaking skills, reading skills, French history, French politics
I know how to learn french by myself: reading novels, listen to french songs, etc
Greater speaking and listening skills some grammar
I learned how to speak better French and understand the language.
I learned a lot about French/Francophonie culture and history through the books/short stories we read this semester.

I became much more proficient at reading writing and speaking French. I learned much more about the relationship between many types of historical discrimination in France and its colonies that still affect the identity of the nation today.
My ability to both speak in and read French improved dramatically this semester.
I improved my listening and speaking abilities and learned a lot of various grammar rules.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I like the course size. The number of students was small enough to have discussions where each student could speak and ask questions. Instructor was great - so friendly, always answered our questions, understood that we wanted to discuss topics outside of the syllabus and have more "conversational" French classes so she built that into the syllabus. I love taking French language classes. It was great to have this class as a constant way for me to practice and improve my French every day. 
Weaknesses: 
-course material is SO irrelevant to daily French life. The vocabulary felt pretty archaic. 
-more contemporary readings and course materials, please. 
-Lingco exam results should stay open for longer so we can review our exams. We never got notifications that our Lingco was open to review. 
-Course packet grammar exercise answers should always be posted after review, so we can fully review them at home and before exams. 
-Course audio is pretty horrible. It was more an exercise in listening to old audio tapes than learning French (lots of crackling, lots of pauses and sound going in and out) 
-Symphony Pastorale should be removed from the syllabus. It's not only boring to read but also problematic course material. Also, the vocabulary we learn from this text is NOT RELEVANT at all to daily speech. I wish I learned from a text that I could better apply to my conversations when I visit France.

It is really good course for improving the french reading skills (tons of novel)
But for speaking and listening skills I feel I am not much improved by the course.
Loved reading Joffo and the books
I felt like the homeworks could be improved and a new course packet should be made. I loved the books that we read but wish they tough us strategies for reading the language.
I really enjoyed the course and don't have any complaints.

I think the course did not allow for as much talking as I would have preferred. It focused heavily on the texts and was less focused on the discussions. When the discussions were emphasized, I thoroughly enjoyed them and thought they were extremely elucitory.
No weaknesses! This course is the perfect blend of assignments, content, and class participation. The introduction of more cultural material this semester was especially interesting.

I thought the course as a whole could be structured to better facilitate learning. The main course packet that the course is based upon lacks neatness and concision. It is filled mostly with exercises and instruction is scattered through. Some exercises also require listening to audio files that can be twenty minutes long with no time stamps. This makes the packet difficult to reference eficiently.
On exams, there are often new cases of grammar rules that weve never covered in class.
Lastly, I think there is too much emphasis and points taken off due to small details like spelling or tense agreement.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If wanting to learn more contemporary French, take a different French course (Business French, for example, or conversational French)
Yes, if someone really want to learn french
Yes! My instructor Clara was the best so kind.
No. It is a lot of assessments and tough grading. The homework is too much. The books were really interesting though.
Yes, I have liked all the French classes I have taken at Yale, so I would definitely recommend progressing through French 4. I learned a lot this semester.
Yes, I think it is really interesting content and would help a student interested in learning French to build their skills
I would 100% recommend this course to anyone who wanted to take French.
